title: Auto-identify
data:
Sometimes, the game will **auto-identify** an [object](/wiki/Object "Object") after [you](/wiki/You "You") or a [monster](/wiki/Monster "Monster") does something with it. This is a contraction for *automatically [identify](/wiki/Identify "Identify")*, and means that you identified a type of object without explicitly using the [scroll of identify](/wiki/Scroll_of_identify "Scroll of identify") or [spellbook of identify](/wiki/Spellbook_of_identify "Spellbook of identify"). Common ways to auto-identify an object include the [engrave-testing](/wiki/Engrave-test "Engrave-test") of [wands](/wiki/Wand "Wand"), letting monsters use certain objects, and (to possibly dangerous effect) yourself using an unidentified object.

Your character now recognizes that type of object; it adds the object to the list of discoveries that appears when you press [\\](/wiki/%5C "\\").

For example, when you hear a monster read an unfamiliar spell [scroll](/wiki/Scroll "Scroll"), then see the monster teleport away, [we](/wiki/We "We") say that the game has *auto-identified* the [scroll of teleportation](/wiki/Scroll_of_teleportation "Scroll of teleportation"). Now, you know which other scrolls (in your [inventory](/wiki/Inventory "Inventory") or elsewhere) are scrolls of teleportation, and you saved a scroll of identify in learning this.

The difference between auto-identification and explicit identification (from the scroll or spell) is that the latter also reveals the [beatitude](/wiki/Beatitude "Beatitude"), [enchantment](/wiki/Enchantment "Enchantment") and [charges](/wiki/Charge "Charge") of one object.

You might still think that you know the identity of an object, even if [NetHack](/wiki/NetHack "NetHack") did not auto-identify it. Suppose that you wore an unidentified ring and quaffed a [potion of enlightenment](/wiki/Potion_of_enlightenment "Potion of enlightenment") to discover that it gave you [cold resistance](/wiki/Cold_resistance "Cold resistance"), or you dropped the ring in a [sink](/wiki/Sink "Sink") and compared the message with a [spoiler](/wiki/Spoiler "Spoiler"). You might know what kind of ring it is, even when the game does not tell you. In these cases, the game will still label the item with its randomized appearance, but you can use the [(N)ame](/wiki/Name "Name") command ([N](/wiki/N "N") if you use the numpad-based control scheme, or #name which always works) to name it yourself. (e.g. the game might still describe that ring of cold resistance as "an engagement ring" but you can (N)ame it "cold resistance" and from then on all engagement rings would be labeled "cold resistance")

[![This article has been updated to reflect NetHack 3.6.1. Click here for more information.](/images/d/d3/Nh361-icon.png)](/wiki/NetHackWiki:Next_version "This article has been updated to reflect NetHack 3.6.1. Click here for more information.")

**This page may need to be updated for the [current version](/wiki/Current_version "Current version") of *NetHack*.**

It may contain text specific to [NetHack 3.6.1](/wiki/NetHack_3.6.1 "NetHack 3.6.1"). Information on this page may be out of date.

**Editors:** After reviewing this page and making necessary edits, please change the {{nethack-361}} tag to the current version's tag or {{noversion}} as appropriate.
html:
Auto-identify

From NetHackWiki
Jump to navigation Jump to search

Sometimes, the game will auto-identify an object after you or a monster does something with it. This is a contraction for automatically identify, and means that you identified a type of object without explicitly using the scroll of identify or spellbook of identify. Common ways to auto-identify an object include the engrave-testing of wands, letting monsters use certain objects, and (to possibly dangerous effect) yourself using an unidentified object.

Your character now recognizes that type of object; it adds the object to the list of discoveries that appears when you press \.

For example, when you hear a monster read an unfamiliar spell scroll, then see the monster teleport away, we say that the game has auto-identified the scroll of teleportation. Now, you know which other scrolls (in your inventory or elsewhere) are scrolls of teleportation, and you saved a scroll of identify in learning this.

The difference between auto-identification and explicit identification (from the scroll or spell) is that the latter also reveals the beatitude, enchantment and charges of one object.

You might still think that you know the identity of an object, even if NetHack did not auto-identify it. Suppose that you wore an unidentified ring and quaffed a potion of enlightenment to discover that it gave you cold resistance, or you dropped the ring in a sink and compared the message with a spoiler. You might know what kind of ring it is, even when the game does not tell you. In these cases, the game will still label the item with its randomized appearance, but you can use the (N)ame command (N if you use the numpad-based control scheme, or #name which always works) to name it yourself. (e.g. the game might still describe that ring of cold resistance as "an engagement ring" but you can (N)ame it "cold resistance" and from then on all engagement rings would be labeled "cold resistance")

This page may need to be updated for the current version of NetHack.

It may contain text specific to NetHack 3.6.1. Information on this page may be out of date.

Editors: After reviewing this page and making necessary edits, please change the {{nethack-361}} tag to the current version's tag or {{noversion}} as appropriate.

Retrieved from "https://nethackwiki.com/index.php?title=Auto-identify&oldid=125049"

rawPage:
Sometimes, the game will '''auto-identify''' an [[object]] after [[you]] or a [[monster]] does something with it. This is a contraction for ''automatically [[identify]]'', and means that you identified a type of object without explicitly using the [[scroll of identify]] or [[spellbook of identify]]. Common ways to auto-identify an object include the [[engrave-test]]ing of [[wand]]s, letting monsters use certain objects, and (to possibly dangerous effect) yourself using an unidentified object.

Your character now recognizes that type of object; it adds the object to the list of discoveries that appears when you press {{kbd|\}}.

For example, when you hear a monster read an unfamiliar spell [[scroll]], then see the monster teleport away, [[we]] say that the game has ''auto-identified'' the [[scroll of teleportation]]. Now, you know which other scrolls (in your [[inventory]] or elsewhere) are scrolls of teleportation, and you saved a scroll of identify in learning this.

The difference between auto-identification and explicit identification (from the scroll or spell) is that the latter also reveals the [[beatitude]], [[enchantment]] and [[charge]]s of one object.

You might still think that you know the identity of an object, even if [[NetHack]] did not auto-identify it. Suppose that you wore an unidentified ring and quaffed a [[potion of enlightenment]] to discover that it gave you [[cold resistance]], or you dropped the ring in a [[sink]] and compared the message with a [[spoiler]]. You might know what kind of ring it is, even when the game does not tell you. In these cases, the game will still label the item with its randomized appearance, but you can use the [[name|(N)ame]] command ({{kbd|N}} if you use the numpad-based control scheme, or #name which always works) to name it yourself. (e.g. the game might still describe that ring of cold resistance as "an engagement ring" but you can (N)ame it "cold resistance" and from then on all engagement rings would be labeled "cold resistance")

[[Category:Strategy]][[Category:Identification]]
{{nethack-361}}
